physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. The main body of the kain panjang features stylised winged animals and birds amongst potted plants. On the left of the kain panjang, there is a vertical panel decorated with opposing triangles. Between the rows of triangles, there is a vertical row of diamonds, each enclosing birds and flowers. There is a signature on the top left of the batik kain panjang.
sgcool_label_text: The main design field (or badan) of this batik is decorated winged animals and fowls amidst potted plants.  On broad vertical panel (kepala), rows of opposing triangles, known as tumpal, are shown.  Square and upright diamonds appear between these rows, each enclosing birds and flowers.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan 100% Tulis”.
